prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Remedies for Breach of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: Permanent injunctions are granted after the trial of an action, when all the issues have been decided, in order to ensure that the actions of the infringing party continue to be prohibited by court order. A permanent injunction can be restricted in time or be perpetual, depending on the circumstances of the case.
A permanent injunction is issued so that:

… those who seek and accept information which they know has been given in confidence for a limited purpose ought not to be able to misuse it, feeling that a money payment will sufficiently balance the present and future injury thereby caused …[1]
A permanent injunction is often used to force the respondent to cease using the moving party's material or pay the price for using the information.

In Sequoia Energy inc. v. Renewable Energy Systems Canada Inc.,[2] Sequoia, a Canadian developer of renewable energy projects in central and western Canada, as well as in certain locations in the United States of America, focusing on run-of-river hydroelectric, utility-scale wind and community scale solar projects, sought a permanent injunction against RES, a Quebec company and a division of a conglomerate of various entities involved in the construction and development of renewable energy projects. RES offers a full range of services associated with renewable energy projects, including their development, construction, operation and maintenance. Sequoia and RES were business competitors but they had also in the past collaborated as partners on various projects. To that end, on November 16, 2012, the parties signed a confidentiality agreement that was to govern their broader relationship even though it appeared from the face of that agreement that it was for the purpose of developing a specific project in Saskatchewan. The Agreement was to be in force for a period of three years and it was to cover all confidential information exchanged between the parties, including any information exchanged prior to its execution.[3]

Sequoia alleged that in breach of the Extended Agreement, RES planned to in the near future, compete with Sequoia in the development and commercialization of a project known as Oyen in the province of Alberta. In September of 2014, Sequoia disclosed to RES certain summary details concerning a potential wind project close to the town of Oyen. Sequoia contended that RES planned to use that information in order to gain a competitive advantage over it in developing a wind farm within the same geographical vicinity. RES did not deny that it obtained certain information from Sequoia but asserted that that information was not confidential and that in any event it “was not useful for any reliable purpose of identifying a wind energy project site in Oyen.”[4]

There was no doubt that certain private information of Sequoia was passed on to RES. Whether or not that information was valuable for RES is not a criteria that the Court need take into consideration. What is important is that the information have the necessary quality of confidence about it.[5]

The second criteria under Lac Minerals requires that the information be imparted in circumstances importing an obligation of confidence. While it was unclear that the private information that was communicated by Sequoia to RES was being communicated in circumstances giving rise to an obligation of confidence, in the face of the Extended Agreement, the Court was prepared to lean in favour of the position advanced by Sequoia and conclude that that information was likely communicated to RES in confidence.[6]

The third criteria set out in Lac Minerals requires an unauthorized use by RES of the private information supplied by Sequoia to its detriment. This was the criteria that Sequoia had clearly failed to satisfy. There was nothing that Sequoia was able to point to that indicated that RES had in any way used the private information supplied to it by Sequoia, including to its detriment.[7]

Even if Sequoia had been able to satisfy the third criteria in Lac Minerals, the Court would have used its discretion to dismiss Sequoia's permanent injunctive demand for two reasons. First, because the facts did not warrant the intrusive remedy. Second, and more importantly, Sequoia failed to convince the Court that it was deserving of such an exceptional and discretionary equitable remedy under the circumstances. Sequoia is a sophisticated and knowledgeable business entity. In the absence of a non-compete engagement, Sequoia failed to demonstrate to this Court why a judicially imposed restraint ought to be imposed on RES's ongoing business activities.[8]

An appropriate remedy in XY Inc. v. International Newtech Development Inc.,[9] was a mandatory and prohibitive injunction. The plaintiff XY owned technology and the intellectual property rights associated with the technology that permitted the separation of X (female) and Y (male) chromosomes from bovine spermatozoa. This technology was used as a means of producing calves of a desired sex. The chromosomes are separated using a cytometer, a device that counts cells. The cytometers that are adapted for this purpose are called SX cytometers. These cytometers are manufactured by D Inc., which had a cross-licensing agreement with XY. On February 6, 2004, the plaintiff entered into a contract called a “Commercial License Agreement” with the defendant now known as JingJing. Under the terms of the contract, JingJing acquired the right to use the plaintiff's technology. In return, it had various obligations, including strict confidentiality, disclosure and assignment to XY of any technological developments, accurate and timely reporting of its use of XY's technology and products, the duty to not sublicense or sub-contract, and the fundamental obligation to pay royalties. The trial concluded that JingJing had, in multiple respects, breached the terms of the Commercial License Agreement. He further concluded that there had been a widespread misuse of XY's confidential technology and information amounting to a breach of confidence.

Injunctive relief was appropriate because the plaintiff was not seeking damages for future breach of confidence. If it were denied, the defendants would be permitted to sort semen using their intimate knowledge of XY's equipment and protocols without paying royalties to XY and in competition with other licensees in China, Canada or elsewhere who do pay royalties. The mandatory injunction was sought to deliver or destroy under oath confidential information of XY which was in the hands of the defendants. The defendants had no right to possess such information. The injunction did no more than hold JingJing and its employees and related companies who had access to the bargain struck under the CLA. Such a mandatory injunction was characterized as an ordinary ancillary remedy in intellectual property cases where an injunction is granted to restrain the use of the information. The court observed that the rationale for an injunction in such circumstances was explained by Binnie J. in Cadbury Schweppes Inc.:

The law would lose its deterrent effect if defendants could misappropriate confidential information and retain profits thereby generated subject only to the payment of compensation if, as and when they are caught and successfully sued.[10]

The main thrust of argument on appeal[11] was that the definition of “Confidential Information” encompassed information that had been made publicly available and thus failed to distinguish between that information and information that is truly confidential. Justice Newberry observed that the starting point for the relevant definition of “Confidential Information” must be the terms of the CLA. As the trial judge noted, the terms of any contract between the parties are relevant to the availability of a claim and therefore, the remedy for breach of confidence. Article 3.10 of the Agreement excepted information that is or becomes generally available to the public other than as a result of a disclosure by the recipient party, and information that was known by the recipient party “on a non-confidential basis and not in contravention of applicable law or confidentiality or other similar agreement prior to disclosure to JingJing by XY. Obviously, this would include published research and patent applications. Justice Newberry concluded that it would not be appropriate, however, for a court to refer to all such patent applications and public research in the terms of an order. While recognizing that any injunction must be clear and enforceable, any question of over breadth could have been avoided by the incorporation of the exceptions listed in s. 3.10 of the CLA. The appeal was allowed to the extent of incorporating the exceptions listed in s. 3.10 of the CLA, with appropriate changes in nomenclature. In all other respects, save one,[12] the appeal concerning the terms of the permanent injunction was dismissed.[13]

In Singh v. Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario et al.,[14] Singh commenced a judicial review application seeking an order setting aside the decision of the Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario to declare Levitt the PC Party nominee for Member of Provincial Parliament for the riding of Hamilton West, quashing the decision of Brown, leader of the PC Party, to terminate Singh's internal appeal of the nomination proceedings, and declaring Singh to be the PC Party nominee for Hamilton West or, alternatively, that the matter be remitted to the PC Party to hold a new nomination meeting. In their Notice of Application, Singh and his nomination campaign pled that the nomination meeting was tainted by a predetermination by PC Party officials prior to voting that Levitt would be the successful candidate, wrongful insertion of false ballots in ballot boxes in favour of Levitt, and exclusion of scrutineers from monitoring of the ballot counting and credential forms process for the ballot box in issue.[15]

Singh's application materials disclosed communications that were made at a meeting that Singh and several of his supporters attended with the Chairman of Brown's campaign for the 2018 Ontario general election. The materials included a transcript of a considerable portion of the Meeting that was made from an audio recording that Singh secretly made at the meeting.[16]

Stanley, in his capacity as Executive Director of the PC Party and on its behalf, supported by the PC Party, moved for a permanent order expunging the Transcript from the record and striking out and expunging three paragraphs from Singh's affidavit that disclosed communications at the Meeting. In support of his motion, Stanley submitted that Singh breached a duty of confidence by disclosing the Transcript and communications at the Meeting and by seeking to admit this information into evidence on his application.[17]

The motions judge concluded that the communications at the Meeting (and the Recording and Transcript) were properly subject to settlement privilege. As such, they were protected from disclosure to others and they were inadmissible in evidence on Singh's judicial review application.[18]

Stanley submitted that, in addition to being privileged, the information Singh sought to disclose was communicated in the strictest confidence and its disclosure to any third parties was a breach of that confidence.[19]

The motions judge concluded that Stanley was not entitled to the permanent injunctive relief for breach of confidence. No proceeding had been commenced by Stanley or the PC Party claiming remedies for a cause of action founded in breach of confidence. There were no pleadings and no motion for summary judgment. Absent a proceeding in which Stanley and the PC Party advanced a claim for the permanent injunctive relief and other related relief founded on a cause of action for breach of confidence, the motions judge was not willing to grant such relief on the motion.[20]

One of the most difficult considerations in determining whether a permanent injunction should be granted is whether the injunction should last until the information becomes public or for some time after that. The courts have held that a responding party should be prevented from using the moving party's confidential information as a “springboard” to obtain an unfair head start.[21] In International Tools Ltd. v. Kollar,[22] the court held that:

Since it is conceivable that sometime in the future, some person other than the plaintiff may by his own thought and effort and quite independently of any improper disclosure of the plaintiff's secret, evolve a manufacturing method embodying the plaintiff's method which constitutes its trade secret, the duration of the injunction should not continue beyond the time the plaintiff's trade secret remains a secret exclusively known to the plaintiff or to those to whom it has been voluntarily disclosed under conditions imposing an obligation of confidentiality upon them.

Where the information has already been made public, the court may grant an injunction for a limited time to enable the innocent party to compete on an equal footing with the offending party, or the court may award the innocent party damages in an amount equal to the advantage gained by the offending party as a result of the wrongful appropriation and use of confidential information.[23]

A permanent injunction may also be granted to enforce a time provision set out in a confidentiality agreement or restrictive covenant.[24] Permanent injunctions are often awarded in such cases, although, in highly technological areas where knowledge changes quickly, there may be little point in seeking such an injunction.

A perpetual injunction may be granted in limited circumstances. The court in A.B. Consolidated Ltd. v. Europe Strength Food Co. Pty. Ltd.[25] granted a perpetual injunction where the defendant deliberately breached its agreement with the plaintiff, the defendant used the information to compete with the plaintiff's existing licensee, and it was doubtful whether the defendant could have discovered the idea on its own.

The appellant also objected that the final prevents him from using “the research and development of the defendants within the Field of Use and outside the Field of Use with respect to in vivo embryos and any other matters using sexed semen”. The term “Field of Use” is defined broadly such that it precludes him from pursuing businesses that involve the production of embryos that are not dependent on XY's technology. XY's rights do not go so far as to entitle it to demand that Mr. Zhu never enter or re-enter that business. He and his companies, however, may not use or build on XY's technology to do so. The impugned paragraph (f) was overly broad. The appeal was allowed to the extent of deleting paragraph (f) of Appendix A to the order.
